name: MUSIC R1B
about:
This course aims to help students improve their writing skil
ls, taking a particular type of music as its central materia
l. The goal of the course is to help students prepare for ac
ademic writing, develop analytical skills appropriate to the
 subject matter, and receive an introduction to college-leve
l research papers. Depending on the topic the course may inc
lude a section of one to two hours for further listening to 
musical examples in a group

name: MUSIC 14
about:
A course in basic vocal techniques, primarily for students i
n the University Choruses, covering techniques of breathing,
 pronunciation, and articulation.

name: MUSIC 20A
about:
Fundamentals of music, including notation, sight singing, ea
r training, and beginning linear analysis. For general stude
nts.

name: MUSIC 24
about:
The Freshman Seminar Program has been designed to provide ne
w students with the opportunity to explore an intellectual t
opic with a faculty member in a small-seminar setting. Fresh
man seminars are offered in all campus departments, and topi
cs vary from department to department and semester to semest
er. Enrollment is limited to 15 freshmen.

name: MUSIC 25
about:
A writing course based on traditional harmony. Beginning lin
ear and vertical analysis. For general students. Emphasis on
 written exercises.

name: MUSIC 26AC
about:
Two perspectives are developed: 1) diverse music of groups i
n America, and 2) American music as a unique phenomenon. Gro
ups considered are African, Asian, European, Hispanic/Latino
, and Native American. Lectures and musical examples are org
anized by topics such as music of socio-economic subgroups w
ithin large groups, survival of culture, pan-ethnicity, reli
gious and concert music, and the folk-popular music continuu
m.

name: MUSIC N26AC
about:
Two perspectives are developed: 1) diverse music of groups i
n America, and 2) American music as a unique phenomenon. Gro
ups considered are African, Asian, European, Hispanic/Latino
, and Native American. Lectures and musical examples are rel
igious and concert music, and the folk-popular music continu
um.

name: MUSIC 27
about:
Devoted to the development of listening skills, and a survey
 of major forms and types of Western art music.

name: MUSIC 28
about:
Opening ears and minds to musical sounds and the people who 
make them, imparting basic concepts and ways of listening in
 order to deepen students' experience of music from a variet
y of cultures, including Western, Middle Eastern, and Southe
ast Asian traditions (specific traditions may vary depending
 on instructor). While the emphasis is on listening, student
s will become physically involved through hands-on workshops
.

name: MUSIC 29
about:
This course explores the basic materials and models that set
 the boundaries for various present-day musical experiences.
 Students are exposed to terminology and modes of engagement
 with the aim of inspiring new paradigms of listening (e.g.,
 listening to silence, noise, space, and timbre). Composers 
and musicians of today continue to explore new ways of defin
ing and organizing sounds into music.

name: MUSIC 39M
about:
Freshman and sophomore seminars offer lower division student
s the opportunity to explore an intellectual topic with a fa
culty member and a group of peers in a small-seminar setting
. These seminars are offered in all campus departments; topi
cs vary from department to department and from semester to s
emester.

name: MUSIC 40
about:
A course designed for students who wish to attain a beginner
's level of proficiency on the carillon. Prospective student
s must have a working knowledge of the keyboard, read treble
 and bass clefs fluently, be secure in key signatures throug
h three sharps and flats, and be comfortable with common dup
le and triple meters.

name: MUSIC 41A
about:
Private carillon lessons to develop a personal repertory. In
 this course, students will begin to learn different practic
e techniques.

name: MUSIC 41B
about:
Private carillon lessons stressing musical questions and de-
emphasizing technical and repertory issues. Composition and 
arranging may be included. Personal musicianship is examined
 and musical horizons are extended.

name: MUSIC 41C
about:
This course is designed for students to reach an advanced le
vel of proficiency. Students are required to play one ten-mi
nute concert per week plus participate in the student recita
l.

name: MUSIC 42
about:
This course is a requirement for those students who are stud
ying for examination by the Guild of Carillonneurs in North 
America.

name: MUSIC 44
about:
Students will learn the fundaments of healthy singing. The c
lassical style will be learned and applied to other styles o
f singing. Students will receive group instruction and indiv
idual feedback throughout the semester. Singers will perform
 two solos: one in English and one in a foreign language. Th
e course is open to all undergraduates. Students involved in
 campus vocal ensembles are encouraged

name: MUSIC 45
about:
Piano instruction includes music theory (musical notation, t
riads, scales and primary chords) at the keyboard. Repertoir
e draws from simple classical pieces and melodies accompanie
d with chords. Mastery of the material will be demonstrated 
at the keyboard and through three written assignments.

name: MUSIC 48
about:
This course is designed to introduce students to the field o
f music therapy with an overview of: what music therapy is, 
bases for uses of music in therapy, key theoretical models o
f music therapy, and clinical applications of music therapy 
with various populations. Through didactic and experiential 
assignments and classroom discussions, we will create a coll
aborative and process-oriented learning environment. Pre-req
uisites: Open to all interested students.

name: MUSIC 52A
about: Diatonic sight singing, ear training, and keyboard harmony.

name: MUSIC 52B
about:

roduction to chromatic sight singing, ear training, keyboard

name: MUSIC 53A
about:

ies. Emphasis on written exercises.

name: MUSIC 53B
about:
Introduction to chromatic harmony and analytical studies. Em
phasis on written exercises.

name: MUSIC 70
about:

study of musical genres and styles in relation to conditions

about:
Directed individual study in a field that may not coincide w

ses and Curricula section of the General Catalog for enrollm
ent restrictions.

name: MUSIC 107
about:
Students will develop, in consultation with the instructor, 
a semester length project that focuses on creating a piece o
f music, and/or researching and building new software tools

about:

about:
This course is intended, above all else, to create the circu

n open mind and a bit of application, we ought to become wel

In-depth study of the Central Javanese gamelan tradition inc

name: MUSIC 137AC

Historical and political analysis of a variety of genres rel
ated to the New Social Movements of the mid-20th century. In
cludes African American, European American, Asian American, 
Latino, and Native American styles.

the impact of government polices on the arts, transnational 
circulation, intellectual property rights, as well as the cu
rrent movements in the arts ranging from popular styles to c
utting-edge contemporary experimentation.

name: MUSIC 154B

name: MUSIC 155

performer/improvisers who have come out of the jazz traditio

This course is intended, above all else, to create the circu
mstances in which we will each independently develop as inti
mate a relationship as we can with Beethoven’s music. With a
n open mind and a bit of application, we ought to become wel
l-acquainted with several of his compositions, extremely fri
endly with others, and perhaps even head over heals in love 
with a couple of them.

Music of the Middle East, including folk, art, popular, and

Historical and political analysis of a variety of genres rel

cludes African American, European American, Asian American, 
Latino, and Native American styles.

about:
Surveys the music and music making of different world cultur

the impact of government polices on the arts, transnational 
circulation, intellectual property rights, as well as the cu
rrent movements in the arts ranging from popular styles to c
utting-edge contemporary experimentation.

A performing course for the study and practice of Indonesian

name: MUSIC N146B
about:
A performing course for the study and practice of Indonesian

name: MUSIC 148
about:
Performance of West African music with particular emphasis o

name: MUSIC N148

Performance of West African music with particular emphasis o

name: MUSIC 149

Performance of Renaissance and Baroque music for voices and

By audition for experienced vocalists. A comprehensive progr

oruses, vocal technique training, and ensemble work with oth

 the course. Each student's studies will lead to some kind o
f public performance.

about:

name: MUSIC 152A
about:
Sight singing, ear training, keyboard harmony, and score rea

name: MUSIC 152B

name: MUSIC 153B

name: MUSIC 154A

A study of species counterpoint. Regular exercises in two an

name: MUSIC 154B
about:
A study of 18th-century counterpoint. Regular exercises requ

ntions, canons, and fugue expositions.

name: MUSIC 155
about:

chniques.

name: MUSIC 156
about:
The study of various analytical techniques and their applica
tion to important works of music.

name: MUSIC 157A

d idiomatic qualities of all of the individual instruments w
hich comprise the contemporary symphony orchestra followed b
y a study of the 18th-, 19th-, and 20th-century orchestratio
nal technique. Analysis of scores and assignments in scoring
 of selected instrumental combinations.

name: MUSIC 157B
about:
A study of instrumentation--the construction capabilities an

hich comprise the contemporary symphony orchestra followed b
y a study of the 18th-, 19th-, and 20th-century orchestratio
nal technique. Analysis of scores and assignments in scoring
 of selected instrumental combinations.

about:

bination of scientific, technological, and artistic methodol
ogies. Musical concerns within a computational frame are add
ressed through the acquisition of basic programming skills f
or the creation and control of digital sound. Will learn cor
e concepts and techniques of computerbased music composition
 using the Cycling74/MaxMSP programming environment in combi
nation

use in musical expression is explored. Students create new i
nstruments and performance environments using a variety of p
hysical interaction paradigms, programming practices, and mu
sical processes emerging from the UC Berkeley Center for New
 Music and Audio Technologies (CNMAT). Building on the metho
dologies established in Music 158A, the course develops aest
hetic, analytic and technical

about:
Software engineering for musical applications covering progr
amming concepts for live-performance real-time systems as we
ll as cloud-based music information retrieval applications. 
Topics include the software representation of sound and musi
c, real-time scheduling, analysis of gestures from systems o
f sensors, common design patterns, analysis and controlled s
ynthesis, and machine learning applications for music unders
tanding and creation.

name: MUSIC 161A
about:
A study of the basic elements of conducting: physical gestur
e, score reading, and score analysis. Development of skills 
with emphasis on conducting and rehearsal techniques applica
ble to orchestral literature in various languages and musica
l styles. Preparation of selected works for rehearsal and pe
rformance in class. Should be taken in a two-semester sequen
ce.

name: MUSIC 161B
about:
A study of the basic elements of conducting: physical gestur

with emphasis on conducting and rehearsal techniques applica
ble to orchestral literature in various languages and musica
l styles. Preparation of selected works for rehearsal and pe
rformance in class. Should be taken in a two-semester sequen
ce.

name: MUSIC 162
about:

que (W evening). Conducting technique classes will be taught

about:

in jazz-based improvisational music. Class participants will

70s up through and including music by contemporary composer/
performer/improvisers who have come out of the jazz traditio
n. Course will also cover related theory and musicianship sk
ills that enable the performer to improvise in this idiom.

side of class time, and will be given individual guidance on

.

about:
This course explores the basic materials and models that set
 the boundaries for various present-day musical experiences.
 Students are exposed to terminology and modes of engagement
 with the aim of inspiring new paradigms of listening (e.g.,
 listening to silence, noise, space, and timbre). Composers 
and musicians of today continue to explore new ways of defin
ing and organizing sounds into music.

. These seminars are offered in all campus departments; topi
